description: From Old English calcatrippe (“plant that trips”), from Medieval Latin calcatrippa (“thistle”), from Latin calx or calcare + trappa.

entries.meaning: (weaponry) A small, metal object with spikes arranged so that, when thrown onto the ground, one always faces up as a threat to pedestrians, horses, and vehicles.
examples: […]  her father, the emperor Alexius, who reigned AD 1081-1118, ordered caltrops to be cast in front of his archers  […]

entries.meaning: (heraldry) The same object represented as a heraldic charge.
(colloquial) The starthistle, Centaurea calcitrapa, a plant with sharp thorns.

Any of a number of flowering plants in the family Zygophyllaceae, including several members of the genus Kallstroemia and the species Tribulus terrestris, native to warm temperate and tropical regions.
